descriptions: The student does not identify any costs or benefits associated with the design solutions.
The student identifies only one or two costs or benefits, and the explanation is superficial.
The student identifies some costs and benefits, but the explanation lacks depth or accuracy.
The student identifies several costs and benefits with reasonable explanations, but there may be some inaccuracies or omissions.
The student identifies most of the relevant costs and benefits with clear and accurate explanations.
The student comprehensively identifies and explains all relevant costs and benefits, demonstrating a thorough understanding.
The student fails to consider any constraints (e.g., cost, safety, reliability, aesthetics, social, cultural, environmental impacts).
The student mentions only one constraint, without any meaningful discussion of its impact.
The student considers a couple of constraints, but the discussion is superficial and lacks connection to the design solutions.
The student considers several constraints and attempts to connect them to the design solutions, but the explanation may lack depth.
The student thoroughly considers most relevant constraints and clearly connects them to the strengths and weaknesses of the design solutions.
The student comprehensively considers all relevant constraints with detailed and insightful explanations of how they impact the feasibility and desirability of the design solutions.
The student does not attempt to evaluate the design solutions or provide any comparison.
The student offers a vague or unsubstantiated opinion about the design solutions.
The student provides a superficial comparison of the design solutions with little supporting evidence.
The student provides a reasonable comparison of the design solutions using some relevant evidence and arguments.
The student provides a well-reasoned and supported comparison of the design solutions, identifying their relative strengths and weaknesses.
The student provides a comprehensive and insightful evaluation of the design solutions, synthesizing evidence and arguments to justify a well-supported conclusion.
The student presents no evidence or reasoning to support their evaluation.
The student uses irrelevant or inaccurate information.
The student uses some evidence, but it is poorly explained or connected to the argument.
The student uses relevant evidence and provides some reasoning, but there may be gaps or inconsistencies.
The student effectively uses relevant evidence and logical reasoning to support their evaluation.
The student skillfully integrates evidence and reasoning to construct a compelling and well-supported argument.
